Articles.Content:
Hey guys,

Here's the Dream Chaser

It is a 1-man shuttle launched atop an Atlas V 402.

It has a docking port in the back and to thrusters for orbital maneuvering.

Launcher thanks to Giggleplex777 !

Download

UPDATE:

Solar panel removed, RTG placed instead.

Ugly parachute removed, installed a better one which is hidden.

Removed unnecessary ASAS.

Launcher optimised.

Useless liquidfuel removed.

Control surfaces tweaked.

Edited April 3, 2014 by iDan122
Wow, that looks cool. How does it attach to the lifter?
Looks great! Where's the liquid fuel and oxidizer for the thrusters on the back?

Wow, that looks cool. How does it attach to the lifter?

THere is a structural birdie with a decoupler.

As well as of the oxidizer, the tank is hidden inside.

Ignore this post- it was written before a nap.

Edited June 13, 2013 by Mekan1k

I made a new Atlas V 402 booster for your Dreamchaser.

http://www./download/m1ak7g0b6tnexo1/DreamChaser.craft

I made a new Atlas V 402 booster for your Dreamchaser.

http://www./download/m1ak7g0b6tnexo1/DreamChaser.craft

Wow nice work! Going to test it out. I will make sure to include your name.

This is awesome, iDan122 nice Dream Chaser and Giggleplex777 nice Atlas booster!

This gave me an idea to make a shuttle

Updated! Giggleplex's launcher now included! 1612 I suggest you don't waste time designing a space shuttle because in KSP it is very hard to make one. I think less than 5 stock shuttles exist out there and they are a lot bigger than yours. It you want to launch that tiny plane, just put it on top of a rocket, you will need less fuel than with this thing. Do not be fooled by how easy it looks, centering thrust with a shuttle is close to impossible.

idan's correct - and it's not only thrust - offcentered mass is a pain too (notably if you try to make a buran like shuttle, which have no main engines on the shuttle, unlike the american shuttle.) shuttle like elements are easier when on top of rockets (you only have to limit the thrust at liftoff to prevent the wings from generating lift - which was a long time a headscratcher for my kliper - too much powerful a rocket, and when i passed a certain speed (the required speed goes up with altitude) the wings started to create lift and made the rocket tumble (extra caution required if you tilt your control surfaces in the VAB )

Edited June 16, 2013 by sgt_flyer

idan's correct - and it's not only thrust - offcentered mass is a pain too (notably if you try to make a buran like shuttle, which have no main engines on the shuttle, unlike the american shuttle.) shuttle like elements are easier when on top of rockets (you only have to limit the thrust at liftoff to prevent the wings from generating lift - which was a long time a headscratcher for my kliper - too much powerful a rocket, and when i passed a certain speed (the required speed goes up with altitude) the wings started to create lift and made the rocket tumble (extra caution required if you tilt your control surfaces in the VAB )

Yes I agree. If you still want to have a go, try replicating Buran, it will be WAY easier to center everything there since the Energia launcher has engines on the fuel tank. Considering the SS, people who made copies put alot of extra engines on it to center the thrust with mass. Also it has to be dynamic since fuel is drained and the center of mass shifts all the time. NASA'S shuttle has thrust vectoringg engines i think.....
However, I do not know how much gimbal angle the engines had. May someone tell me something about it?

*snip* I suggest you don't waste time designing a space shuttle because in KSP it is very hard to make one. I think less than 5 stock shuttles exist out there and they are a lot bigger than yours. It you want to launch that tiny plane, just put it on top of a rocket, you will need less fuel than with this thing. Do not be fooled by how easy it looks, centering thrust with a shuttle is close to impossible.

While you are correct in many regards, I disagree with you on dissuading 1612 from trying to construct a functional shuttle. They are challenging to make, but as long as you have a decent grasp on the concepts of thrust vectoring, COM displacement, and torque they are substantially easier to engineer. There are many valuable physics lessons to be learned during the creation of a shuttle (plus they are just plain cool!).

On the contrary; because it is hard, it is the reason why it must be done!

@1612: Excellent shuttle you have there!

@Henry Von Braun: I believe that the SSME's have a 10.5 degree gimbal range. In fact, here is a excerpt from a document from Nasa (<----Click here!) to back it up! "Each engine can be gimbaled plus or minus 10.5 degrees in the yaw axis and plus or minus 10.5 degrees in the pitch axis for thrust vector control by hydraulically powered gimbal actuators."

Edited June 16, 2013 by Amloris

Energia style boosters are also a big pain in the butt.

My Ployus couldn't fly higher than 20km.
Yeah but I think none of the engines in KSP have such a imbalance range. That's why many just use 90Ã‚Â° engines on the fuel tank.
This rocket doesn't need RCS or extra boosters.

Alright, I did not think of putting it on top.

My shuttle does work as planned, NO hotkeys.
I might revive this soon.
Guys I updated the shuttle, now compatible with the newest release.
Nice! I changed a few things, it can now basically land itself now
How the heck does that work? Mechjeb? No mod parts on this beauty! Stock is always more popular than modded.
The shuttle was featured on Spooty's twitch channel!(KSPTV broadcaster)
Wee! That will supply my already ruined Mun Space station! I am so screwed in Science mode! I'm so screwed it's past the point of funny.
I'm not sure if it can go to the Mun, haven't tested it for that yet, but it has some fuel in the Centaur once in orbit.
Ok I updated some pics, new ones are of much better quality.
